Manning, George Henry
Box 85, Rosetown.
To Sask. - Apr 11, 1921

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES
NO. 2
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE
A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual will be asked to answer it. It has already been answered by many others who have lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diary: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being obtained. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

{ } All questionnaires
{ } Pioneer health conditions
{ } Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
{ } Pioneer housing and churchwork
{ } Pioneer education and churchwork
{ } Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the persons answering the following questions:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire like on pioneer life, because no individual was asked to answer it. It has exactly the same effect as another. Some of the questions will not apply to others, but they may prove interesting. If the answers are given in detail, or describe particular events, it helps to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Days: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Enjoy?", is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at all later dates. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as given, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: G.E.R.G.E. HENRY, M.M.A., N.W.T.
2. Your address: Box 85, Rosetown, S.A.S.K.
3. Date: January 14th, 1952.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Hadleigh, Suffolk, England, 1812.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Robert - Homesteader.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April - 1901.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Meadowlee, Man., April 1st - June 1894; Stonewall, April 1st - April 1901.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you could not or you may use "I was a small child").
9. What were your reasons for coming West?: Hope of bettering our living.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Hearing or government information?):
    Reading about Canada - at that time - the newspapers and steamship company were flooding the old land and advertising Canada as the skin and adventure.
Manning, George Henry
Box 65, Rosetown.
To Sask. - April, 1901.

1. Your full name: G.S.R.G.F. HENRY... MANNING...
2. Your address: Box 65... ROSETOWN... SASK...
3. Date: January 17th, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   HADLEIGH... SUFFOLK ENGLAND 1812
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   ROBERT - Manning
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   1901 - 1901
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan giving dates wherever possible.
   MEADOWLEE... MAN. April till June 1894
   STONEWALL... July 1894 till April 1901
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may just say "I was a small child")
   I was in my teens, etc.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Hope of bettering our living
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroads or government information?)
    Reading about Canada - all their tours - the railroads and steamship company were glorifying Canada & its soil with advertisements, reading Canada & the Sun

White woodcut out wind to go to church usually - five miles

On land - horse & wagon - or buggy

On trail - oxen & wagon or buckboard - than lower & Homesteaders' dogs - Omen & wagons or oxen unroaded way
